<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 343, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Probability & Statistics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 97, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 710, 92]]<|/det|> The probability distribution table for a random variable \(X\) is shown below. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[237, 100, 798, 149]]<|/det|>
\(x\)\(-2\)\(-1\)0.512
\(\mathrm {P}(X=x)\)0.12\(p\)\(q\)0.160.3
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 163, 611, 183]]<|/det|> Given that \(\mathrm {E}(X)=0.28\), find the value of \(p\) and the value of \(q\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|> The Lions and the Tigers are two basketball clubs. The heights, in cm, of the 11 players in each of their first team squads are given in the table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 115, 836, 163]]<|/det|>
Lions178186181187179190189190180169196
Tigers194179187190183201184180195191197
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 179, 146, 197]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 178, 920, 212]]<|/det|> Draw a back-to-back stem-and-leaf diagram to represent this information, with the Lions on the left. [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 522, 148, 541]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 522, 855, 541]]<|/det|> Find the median and the interquartile range of the heights of the Lions first team squad. [3] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 667, 920, 700]]<|/det|> It is given that for the Tigers, the lower quartile is \(183\mathrm{cm}\), the median is \(190\mathrm{cm}\) and the upper quartile is \(195\mathrm{cm}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 714, 146, 732]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 714, 920, 747]]<|/det|> Make two comparisons between the heights of the players in the Lions first team squad and the heights of the players in the Tigers first team squad. [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 765, 920, 784]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
In a large population, the systolic blood pressure (SBP) of adults is normally distributed with mean 125.4 and standard deviation 18.6.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 774, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the SBP of a randomly chosen adult is less than 132.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
The SBP of 12-year-old children in the same population is normally distributed with mean 117. Of these children \(88\%\) have SBP more than 108.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 507, 146, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 507, 534, 525]]<|/det|>
Find the standard deviation of this distribution.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 507, 920, 525]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 567, 92]]<|/det|>
Three adults are chosen at random from this population.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that each of these three adults has SBP within 1.5 standard deviations of the mean.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
A game is played with an ordinary fair 6-sided die. A player throws the die once. If the result is 2, 3, 4 or 5, that result is the player's score and the player does not throw the die again. If the result is 1 or 6, the player throws the die a second time and the player's score is the sum of the two numbers from the two throws.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 146, 168]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 149, 670, 170]]<|/det|>
Draw a fully labelled tree diagram to represent this information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 151, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 521, 425, 540]]<|/det|>
Events \(A\) and \(B\) are defined as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 542, 648, 562]]<|/det|>
\[A\colon \mathrm{the~player^{\prime}s~score~is~5,~6,~7,~8~or~9}\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 564, 584, 584]]<|/det|>
\[B\colon \mathrm{the~player~has~two~throws}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 606, 146, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 604, 321, 624]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\mathrm{P}(A) = \frac{1}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 606, 920, 624]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 626, 91]]<|/det|>
Determine whether or not events \(A\) and \(B\) are independent.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 510, 280, 528]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(B \mid A')\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
